review.title: Identifying Topology of Power Distribution Networks Based on Smart Meter Data
review.abstract: In a power distribution network, the network topology information is essential for an efficient operation of the network. This information of network connectivity is not accurately available, at the low voltage level, due to uninformed changes that happen from time to time. In this paper, we propose a novel data--driven approach to identify the underlying network topology including the load phase connectivity from time series of energy measurements. The proposed method involves the application of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and its graph-theoretic interpretation to infer the topology from smart meter energy measurements. The method is demonstrated through simulation on randomly generated networks and also on IEEE recognized Roy Billinton distribution test system.
histories: Submitted to IEEE transaction on smart grid
review.COMMENTS: Submitted to IEEE transaction on smart grid

metadata.title: Identifying Topology of Power Distribution Networks Based on Smart Meter Data

sections.heading: II. PRELIMINARIES
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
sections.text: It is one of the widely used tools of multivariate data analysis with many applications. It was primarily developed as a method for decoding data and dimensionality reduction (24). Recently, PCA was applied to identify a model in the presence of noise [24], [25]. In this paper, we will use the method of identification with PCA from measurements and, we will revisit it. (1) Model identification with PCA: Let zm (j) be defined as a sample of n variables measured in the jth time, as follows: zm (j) = [zm1), z m 2 (j), z m n (j). The measured values are corrupted by random noise, resulting in an error in the samples. The vector of the measured variables can be written as follows: zm (j) = zt (j).

sections.heading: B. Graph Theory Overview
sections.text: In this section, certain concepts of algebraic graph theory that belong to this work are revised. 1) Graph and sub-graph: A graph G = (NG, NE) contains a series of nodes (NG) and edges (NE) whose connectivity represents a network of physical or abstract elements. A graph should be directed if its edges are directed from one node to another. S is a sub-graph of G with a set of nodes NS-NG and edges ES-EG, so that ES contains all edges with both endpoints in NS. A graph should be connected if there is a path between each pair of its nodes, otherwise the graph will be separated. The connected sub-graphs of a separate graph are referred to as its components. 2) Tree: A tree is a graph without circuits (or loops) and two nodes in a tree can be connected by a unique path.

sections.heading: C. Types of Distribution Networks
sections.text: Based on the topology of the network, the distribution networks are classified as follows: i Radial distribution network: In this configuration, each of the feeders and distributors is fed from a single source. Therefore, this type of network is characterized by the presence of a unique path from the source (substation) to each consumment.ii Main distribution network of the ring: In this configuration, the feeders and distributors can be connected to multiple sources to ensure greater reliability of the power supply. Therefore, multiple sources are available to feed a load, and there may be multiple paths between these sources and loads. However, the circuit breakers are configured during network operation to supply only one source to a load, and an electrically active path between them is unique. Therefore, the active network can still be considered radial.

sections.heading: III. PROBLEM FORMULATION
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Distribution Network as a Tree
sections.text: The topology of a distribution network can be considered as the connectivity between the meters, feeders, transformers and power grids installed in the substation. A diagram can be created by assigning nodes to each of the meters and displaying the connections between them. 4 NodeFeeder & Transformer NodesConsumer NodesFig. 2: Tree representation of Network Topologyas edges. Since the paths from the substation to each of the consumers are unique, as described in Section II-C. The diagram of a distribution network is a tree, as shown in Fig. 2. For the meters of 3-phase consumers and 3-phase transformers, we assign three separate nodes corresponding to each of the three phases to maintain consistency with the single-phase consumers. The main advantage of such assignment is that it also allows us to determine the phase identity of single-phase consumers.

sections.heading: B. Energy measurements
sections.text: Since we assume that smart meters are installed at all nodes in the network, energy measurements in watt hours (Wh) are collected at regular intervals, usually fifteen or thirty minutes, at a central location and stacked into a data matrix, Z: Z = [zij] (n · N) (17), where zij, henceforth referred to as zmi (j), the energy measurement corresponds to the ith node in the jth time interval, n the number of nodes in the network and N the number of measurements recorded per node.

sections.heading: C. Energy Conservation
sections.text: In this section, the concept of energy saving is illustrated by an example. Consider a diagram of an electricity grid with eight energy meters (referred to as nodes 1, 2,.., 8) connected by seven power lines (referred to as edges a, b,.., g), as shown in Fig. 3. The incoming energy is recorded at each node by an energy meter. The principle of energy saving implies that the sum of the energies of incoming lines is equal to the sum of the energies of outgoing lines at each node. Take noise-free readings at nodes 1, 2,..., 8 in Fig. 3, by applying the principle of energy saving, for all times j = 1,., N: zt1 (j) (j) = 2 (j) + z t 3 (j).

sections.heading: D. Losses and Errors
sections.text: In practice, we need to consider various sources of noise in the measurements in order to be able to infer the underlying topology with the help of data. (These sources of noise and their contributions in the measurements are nex.1) Technical losses: The technical losses include the constant losses such as iron losses, dielectric losses and the variable losses such as copper losses. The latter vary with the load in the network and also depend on the length of the measurement lines. These losses are modeled as errors in the measurements, as they affect the energy savings between the node measurements. Let is n-dimensional vector of technical losses for the n lines in the last time interval. They can be modeled as Gaussian with a non-zero mean, and heteroscedastic deviations as follows.

sections.heading: IV. PHASE AND TOPOLOGY IDENTIFICATION
sections.text: In this section, the following assumptions are made: 1) There is no power theft and there are no untold loads in the network. 2) The topology of the underlying network remains unchanged while the N measurements are recorded.

sections.heading: B. Topology Identification
sections.text: The solution to the phase identification problem can be extended to the topology identification problem by visualizing the tree structures in a multi-layered way. Nodes of the tree can be divided into layers, with each layer having meters (nodes) operating at a known tension level, as in Fig. 4. Any amount of two successive layers, when visualized separately, appears as forest-directed trees. Now, the problem is reduced to finding the connectivity of a forest of directed trees, which is similar to the phase identification problem. By deriving the connectivity between all possible successive layers, the entire network topology can be identified. Let the layers be numbered from bottom to top, as in Fig. 4. Let nl be the number of layers and Nl be the number of nodes in layer. Let zTi be the ith series of the data matrix Z.

sections.heading: V. SIMULATION RESULTS
sections.text: The proposed algorithms are demonstrated by simulations on noisy data sets. Simulations are performed on MATLAB R © 2014a.7.

sections.heading: A. Phase Identification
sections.text: The network is constructed using random number generators in MATLAB R ©, as follows: 1) The number of consumers connected per phase is randomly (uniformly) selected between 75 and 100. 2) The N measurements for each of the consumer meters are taken from one of the three uniform distributions, with ranges (0 − 100), (0 − 300) and (0 − 500) to take into account for consumers with different ranges of load. 3) Now, the N measurements for each of the three phase meters are determined by summing the measurements of the consumers connected to them, or. 4) The relative distances of consumers from the transformer are randomly assigned, from a series of numbers. The product of these distances is taken with the respective consumer measurements and scaled to the range (5 − 10). Since the technical losses of consumer loads and their distances depend on the transformer, these products are taken as percentages over the consumer measurements to calculate losses.

sections.heading: B. Topology Identification
sections.text: The proposed algorithm for topology identification is tested by simulation of data for bus 2 of the Roy Billinton Distribution Test System [29], which, according to our formulation, has 2004 nodes. The simulation is performed as follows: 1) The N-values for each of the metering devices were selected from a uniform distribution, with mean and maximum values corresponding to the average and peak loads of the consumers, as mentioned in [29]. 2) The relative distances of the consumers from their source transformer and those of the transformers from their source feeder devices were randomly assigned. 3) The transformer and feeder metering values are then determined in each of the N-time intervals by an appropriate summation of the metering values. 4) The noise in the samples due to technical losses, random errors and time synchronization errors are added in a similar way as described in section V-A. The above simulation is repeated 10 times with different number of metering values from N., the success rate and the algorithms are shown in table II.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The proposed approach uses PCA and its graph theory interpretation to derive the topology from energy measurements; the proposed algorithms have been confirmed by simulation of random networks and also by simulation of the Roy Billinton Distribution Test System. The proposed method accurately derives the underlying topology when sufficient data is available; in addition, the problem can be solved in polynomic time, and therefore the solution can be easily put into practice. 8 In the future, we propose to use this technique to solve the problems of detecting changes in topology, loss estimation and detection of non-technical losses such as power theft. We also propose to expand this approach to include the underlying network of missing data scenarios.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
sections.text: We would like to thank Prof. S. Narasimhan from IIT Madras for his valuable contributions.

referenceMentions.context: Research is actively pursued in the areas of control and automation of distribution networks, and in many cases, it is assumed that network topology information is available [1]–[3].
Research is actively pursued in the areas of control and automation of distribution networks, and in many cases, it is assumed that network topology information is available [1]–[3].
The information of the underlying network topology is useful for efficient integration of renewable energy sources and efficient management of outages in distribution networks [4], [5].
The information of the underlying network topology is useful for efficient integration of renewable energy sources and efficient management of outages in distribution networks [4], [5].
Further, for a reliable state estimation in a distribution network, accurate information of the network topology is essential [6].
Unbalanced loads on transformers and feeders lead to higher copper losses and voltage drop, and consequently affect the life of the assets [7].
The network topology information might not be accurately available at all time because of changes that take place due to network reconfiguration, repairs, maintenance and load balancing [7], [8].
The network topology information might not be accurately available at all time because of changes that take place due to network reconfiguration, repairs, maintenance and load balancing [7], [8].
Often, the network operators are not aware of such changes in the topology [9].

Hardware based methods include microprocessor based phase identification system and signal injection device designed for phase measurement [10], [11].
One is a search algorithm to determine phase information using power flow measurements and load data [12].
Another method proposed real–time monitoring of changes in the underlying network topology based on the status of circuit breakers [13].
The latest methods include optimization based approach to infer phase connectivity and also network topology from time series of power measurements [14], [15].
The latest methods include optimization based approach to infer phase connectivity and also network topology from time series of power measurements [14], [15].
In [16], a technique to identify the phases based on cross-correlation method using the time series of voltage measurements, is presented.
[17] proposed a linear regression based algorithm for phase identification which considers the correlation between consumer voltage and substation voltage.
In another method for phase identification, data obtained from micro synchrophasor measurement units (μPMU) is analysed [18].
In [6], [19], methods were proposed to infer topology from time series of measurements from PMUs.
In [6], [19], methods were proposed to infer topology from time series of measurements from PMUs.
In [20], an algorithm to identify the network topology using voltage correlation analysis is presented.
In [21], a hypothesis testing based technique to the topology identification is proposed using the signals generated by the PLC network laid in a smart grid.

Our approach integrates PCA and its graphtheoretic interpretation (as shown in [22]) to identify the network topology from time series of energy measurements, based on the principle of energy conservation.
As a preliminary, in our prior work [23], we introduced this approach for phase identification.

Assuming that the computational power used in both the cases to be of same order, our method clearly outperforms the method proposed in [14], in terms of time.

To compare the success rate of our algorithm with that proposed in [14], phase identification of 10 randomly generated networks with upto 200 consumer nodes, was performed using both the algorithms and the success rates are reported in Table I.

Topology Identification The proposed algorithm for Topology Identification is tested by simulating data for the Bus 2 of Roy Billinton distribution test system [29], which has 2004 nodes as per our formulation.

The simulation is conducted as follows: 1) The N readings for each of the consumer meters were sampled from a uniform distribution with mean and maximum equal to the average and peak loads of the consumers, as mentioned in [29].

metadata.abstractText: In a power distribution network, the network topology information is essential for an efficient operation of the network. This information of network connectivity is not accurately available, at the low voltage level, due to uninformed changes that happen from time to time. In this paper, we propose a novel data– driven approach to identify the underlying network topology including the load phase connectivity from time series of energy measurements. The proposed method involves the application of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and its graph-theoretic interpretation to infer the topology from smart meter energy measurements. The method is demonstrated through simulation on randomly generated networks and also on IEEE recognized Roy Billinton distribution test system.
